definition: Zhang Xun (1854-1923), Qing loyalist general who attempted to restore the abdicated emperor Puyi 溥儀|溥仪[Pu3 yi2] to the throne in the Manchu Restoration of 1917 張勳復辟|张勋复辟[Zhanɡ1 Xun1 Fu4 bi4]
surname Zhang
to open up/to spread/sheet of paper/classifier for flat objects, sheet/classifier for votes
variant of 勛|勋[xun1]
variant of 勛|勋[xun1]
medal/merit
Manchu Restoration of 1917, an attempt by general 張勳|张勋[Zhanɡ1 Xun1] to reinstate the monarchy in China by restoring the abdicated emperor Puyi 溥儀|溥仪[Pu3 yi2] to the throne

sentences.english: They defeated Zhang Xun and put on end to this restoration farce.
sentences.chinese: 他们打败了张勋，结束了这场复辟丑剧。

definition: Duan Qirui (1864-1936), commander of Beiyang Army under Yuan Shikai, then politician and powerful warlord
Cao Kun (1862-1938), one of the Northern Warlords
north China army, a modernizing Western-style army set up during late Qing, and a breeding ground for the Northern Warlords after the Qinghai revolution
Ni Sichong (1868-1924), general closely linked to Yuan Shikai 袁世凱|袁世凯 during his unsuccessful 1915 bid for Empire
Manchu Restoration of 1917, an attempt by general 張勳|张勋[Zhanɡ1 Xun1] to reinstate the monarchy in China by restoring the abdicated emperor Puyi 溥儀|溥仪[Pu3 yi2] to the throne
Feng Yuxiang (1882-1948), warlord during Republic of China, strongly critical of Chiang Kai-shek
Fengtian clique (of northern warlords)
the Northern Expeditionary Army
Lu Rongting (1858-1928), provincial governor of Guangxi under the Qing, subsequently leader of old Guangxi warlord faction
Sun Chuanfang (1885-1935) one of the northern warlord, murdered in Tianjin in 1935
Beiyang faction of Northern Warlords
Xu Shichang (1855-1939), politician associated with the Northern Warlords, president of China in 1921
Yuan Shikai (1859-1916), senior general of late Qing, subsequently warlord and self-proclaimed emperor of China
Zhao Erxun (1844-1927), modern historian, compiled the Draft History of the Qing dynasty 清史稿
the Zhili faction of the Northern Warlords
the Northern Warlords (1912-1927)
